text: Section 420 of the Indian Penal Code deals with cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property. The punishment includes imprisonment up to 7 years and fine.
The Supreme Court of India has interpreted Section 420 in numerous cases, establishing that the essential ingredients are fraud and dishonest inducement.
Under the Criminal Procedure Code, offenses under Section 420 are cognizable and non-bailable, requiring police investigation without warrant.
Section 302 of the Indian Penal Code defines punishment for murder. The death penalty or life imprisonment may be imposed based on the circumstances of the case.
The Indian Evidence Act governs the admissibility of evidence in court proceedings. Section 3 defines what constitutes relevant evidence.
The Constitution of India provides fundamental rights to all citizens. Article 21 guarantees the right to life and personal liberty.
The High Courts have jurisdiction over states and can hear appeals from lower courts. They also have original jurisdiction in certain matters.
Criminal procedure in India follows the Code of Criminal Procedure 1973. It outlines the process for investigation, trial, and appeal.
The doctrine of basic structure was established by the Supreme Court to prevent destruction of the Constitution's essential features.
Legal precedent plays a crucial role in Indian jurisprudence. Decisions of higher courts bind lower courts in similar cases.
Section 376 of the Indian Penal Code deals with rape and specifies punishments ranging from 7 years to life imprisonment.
The Code of Criminal Procedure provides for anticipatory bail under Section 438, allowing a person to seek bail before arrest.
The Indian Contract Act governs contracts and agreements. It defines what constitutes a valid contract and remedies for breach.
The Supreme Court is the highest court in India with original, appellate and advisory jurisdiction.
Section 498A of the Indian Penal Code addresses cruelty against married women and provides for imprisonment up to 3 years.
